Among them, graphene, consisting of atomically thin layers of sp2 bonded carbon atoms, has attracted extensive investigations because of its exceptional physical, chemical, optical, and mechanical properties.[2] Since the recognition of graphene by Nobel Prize in 2010,[3] other 2D materials have also attracted much renewed attentions, which include hexagonal boron nitrides,[4] transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs),[5] metal oxides,[6] black P,[7] silicene,[8] germanene,[9] and MXenes.[10]
Among these 2D nanomaterials, 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides and carbonitrides (collectively denoted as
MXenes) have rapidly expanded since the discovery of Ti3C2 in 2011. MXenes are the rising-star materials which have been extensively investigated because of their similarity to graphene. First, both graphene and MXene can be obtained via a “topdown”exfoliation method from their bulk counterparts (graphite or a MAX material). This exfoliation method enables production of large-scale ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with thicknesses down to single atom or a few atomic layers, which can lead to many unique physical and chemical properties. Second, ideal graphene and MXene materials are highly conductive and have high specific surface area, which is beneficial for many potential applications in energy storage and conversion. Thirdly, the graphene and MXene also have many similar modification methods to tune morphology, crystalline structure and surface properties for specific applications. Typically, the porosity and curvature of graphene and MXene can be adjusted to produce more specific surface area and pore volumes. Furthermore, the microstructure of graphene and MXene materials can be also modified with heteroatoms (metal or nonmetal) doping and surface modifications to achieve higher performance. This similarity provides promising perspectives of MXene-based materials for energy storage and conversion applications.[11]
Nowadays, electric vehicles (EVs) and next-generation smart electricity grids demand high energy, high power and outstanding long-term properties to ensure consistent energy supply. In this regard, the development of large scale high performance energy storage systems is critical to integrate renewable energy resources into high power energy applications.[12] So far, many renewable energy storage technologies have been proposed and developed, including lithium-ion
2D MXene-based nanomaterials have attracted tremendous attention because of their unique physical/chemical properties and wide range of applications in energy storage, catalysis, electronics, optoelectronics, and photonics. However, MXenes and their derivatives have many inherent limitations in terms of energy storage applications. In order to further improve their performance for practical application, the nanoengineering of these 2D materials is extensively investigated. In this Review, the latest research and progress on 2D MXene-based nanostructures is introduced and discussed, focusing on their preparation methods, properties, and applications for energy storage such as lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, lithium– sulfur batteries, and supercapacitors. Finally, the critical challenges and perspectives required to be addressed for the future development of these 2D MXene-based materials for energy storage applications are presented.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Over the last decade, 2D materials, defined as materials with thicknesses of a few atomic layers and very high aspect ratios, have garnered tremendous interest in many applications.[1] Owing to their 2D nature, nanosheet-like materials exhibit extremely high specific surface areas, and may exhibit

batteries, sodium-ion batteries, lithium–sulfur batteries, and supercapacitors.[13] However, the full development of these storage technologies faces a number of issues: i) The fundamental mechanism of the lithium-ion batteries relies on lithium ion insertion/extraction into or from the electrodes during the charge/discharge processes. Although lithium-ion batteries have high energy density, they are low power devices (slow charge/discharge). The intrinsic diffusion dynamics of lithium-ions in the solid-state electrode materials inevitably limits the rate of intercalation/deintercalation.[14] ii) The fundamental mechanism of sodium-ion batteries is similar to that of lithium-ion batteries, depending on the intercalation/deintercalation of sodium-ions into/out of cathodes and anodes. However, due to the larger size of sodium-ion compared with lithium-ion, the dynamics of sodium ion diffusion in the solid state is inferior to that of lithium-ion.[15] iii) For lithium–sulfur batteries, the intrinsic insulating nature of sulfur causes poor power density. On the other hand, the discharge products (polysulfides) are soluble in organic electrolytes. The sulfur species can diffuse through the separator membrane and subsequently lead to the loss of active material during cycling. Thus, lithium–sulfur batteries suffer from poor cyclability owing to this “shuttle effect.”[16] iv) Compare to batteries, supercapacitors have high power and long cycle life. They are also environmentally friendly, highly safe, and can be operated in a relatively wide temperature range. A main disadvantage of supercapacitors is their low energy density compared to batteries, and thus their applications are still limited in terms of specific energy and volumetric energy.[17] Towards above mentioned energy storage systems, ideal 2D MXene sheets cannot achieve practical applications because of the instinct drawbacks of MXenes such as low capacity, low capacitance, and inferior retention owing to the undesirable complex surface functional groups and unreactive microstructure. Therefore, nanoengineering techniques on novel MXene materials such as surface modification, morphology control, and composite formation are critically desired to improve the performance of energy storage systems and solve the above-mentioned challenges for developing high performance energy storage technologies.
In this review, we summarize recent research progresses on nanoengineering of 2D MXenes and their derivatives with enhanced performance for energy storage applications such as lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, lithium–sulfur batteries, and supercapacitors. We discuss their functionalization to achieve improved properties which cover synthesis, physical and chemical characterizations, computational modelings, and electrochemical properties. Last, we outline the crucial challenges and perspectives on the research and development of 2D MXene materials for energy storage applications.

sections.heading: 2. Preparation and Properties of MXenes
sections.text:
MXenes reported to date are mostly synthesized by selective removal of certain atomic layers from their precursors, e.g., MAX phases or their analogues. MAX phases are a large family of layered carbides and nitrides with over 70 members. Different from the synthesis of MoS2 and graphene materials, etching is essential in preparation of MXenes due to the strong
metallic bonds between A and M elements in MAX phase that make mechanical exfoliation difficult. Because M-X bonds are more chemically stable than the M-A bonds so that the selective etching of A layers is possible.[18]

Borysiuk et al. used molecular dynamic simulations demonstrating that titanium carbides are stiffer and stronger than MoS2, a little weaker than graphene.[20]
The preparation of 2D MXene nanosheets associates with etching of A atoms and delamination of multilayer to few layers even single layer. The etching and delamination processes can be carried out separately or simultaneously, as illustrated in Figure 1a. The wet etching with aqueous hydrofluoric acid (HF) or HF-forming or HF-containing solutions is the mainstream approach for the preparation of MXenes. This exfoliated procedure leads to the selective removal of the A-containing layers and their replacement by -OH, -O, and -F functional groups, which enable high hydrophilicity of the materials. There are many different protocols for producing MXenes, and one synthesis strategy may be suitable for one kind of precursor but not applicable for another precursor. Even for the certain kind of MXene, there are several different synthesis routes reported, which influence the resulting chemical/physical properties so that directly affect the performance of MXenes in their applications.[21] The etching conditions vary from one kind of precursors to another, predominantly depending on the atomic bond of the material. Cr-, Mo-, Nb-, Ta-, V-, and Zr-containing MXenes require aggressive etching conditions compared with
Ti-containing MXene materials. Ti2CTx can be obtained after 10 h of etching in 10 wt% HF, while V2CTx required 90 h of treatment in 50 wt% HF. Although HF is widely used for the production of MXenes since its first introduction in 2011, single-layer MXene nanosheets were obtained by intercalating large organic molecules and delaminating the accordion-like sheets from each other in 2013, which open a gate to exploration of real monolayer 2D MXenes.[22] Many organic materials have been reported for this purpose, such as dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO), isopropyl amine, chloroform, tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH), and so on (Figure 1b).[23] The organic molecules first intercalated into the multilayered MXenes and then delaminated in water forming a colloidal solution via sonication or mechanical shaking.[24]
Besides the HF etching method, MXenes were subsequently synthesized by moderate routes using HF-containing (NH4HF2) or HF-contained (LiF + HCl) etching agent, which lowered the risk of handling the concentrated HF. Moreover, the cations (e.g., NH4+ and Li+) and water molecular can simultaneously intercalate into the layered structure of MXenes. Therefore, the resulting MXenes have a larger interlayer distance than that of HF-etched MXenes, which weakens the interactions between layers and contributes to the delamination of materials during sonication. Thus, this method simplifies the aforementioned laborious multistep synthetic procedures, realizing the possibility of one step for the preparation of MXenes.[25]

Due to the fluoride-contained acidic solution are corrosive and toxic, many other safe and economic etching agencies have been widely investigated. For example, Yang et al. demonstrated a fluoride-free electrochemical approach for the delamination of Ti3C2 in a binary aqueous electrolyte, achieving high production yield of Ti3C2Tx nanosheets (Figure 1c). In this approach, Al atoms were etched by chloride ions in an anodic etching process and the subsequent intercalation of ammonium hydroxide enables to exfoliate the edges of the etched anode on the surfaces. Due to the exclusion of F, the exfoliated Ti3C2Tx (T = O, OH) flakes without fluorine terminations. exhibit a remarkable areal capacitance in supercapacitor application.[26] Besides acidic etching, a more economic approach utilizes high temperature and high concentration of basic solution (NaOH) to dissolve the A layer in MAX (Figure 1d). The process is also fluorine-free and yields multilayer Ti3C2Tx (T = O, OH) as high as 92 wt%.[27]
Other methods such as molten salt, salt templated, and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) approaches are possible for the synthesis of MXenes as well.[28] The explorations of these strategies facilitate the studies of the MXenes, particularly the Mo2C and MoN 2D structured materials prepared from the bottom-up synthesis methods have many defects and thus benefit the investigation for their intrinsic properties. However, existing routes are yet to be widely employed for energy storage owing to their complexity. Further explorations via bottom-up synthesis routes are required to scale up the preparation of MXenes. MXenes can be produced by many wet etching methods and subsequent exfoliation technology.[29–37]
The electronic properties of MXenes vary from semiconducting to metallic, depending on the nature of M, X elements and the functional groups on surface. Using first-principle calculations, Khazaei et al. examined the electronic properties of M2X systems chemically functionalized by F, OH, and O groups, respectively.[38] Their calculation shows that Sc2C, Ti2C, Zr2C, and HF2C are expected to become semiconductors upon appropriate surface functionalization. Whereas, results demonstrate that the electronic structures of thicker MXene sheets such as Ti3C2, Ti4C3, Ti4N3, V3C2, Nb4C3, and Ta3C2 with a larger number of transition metals remain metallic upon any kind of the functionalization. These MXenes with high electronic conductivities can facilitate ionic and electronic transport when they are employed as electrode materials, inspiring their application for electrochemical energy storage. For example, the conductivity of Ti3C2Tx can reach 4600 S cm−1 for mild-etched and delaminated vacuum filtered films, which is even higher than the solution-processed graphene.[39] The excellent electronic conductivity with the addition of facile synthetic process of Ti3C2Tx boost the relating studies, rendering it becomes the mostly studied material in the MXene family.
The stability of MXenes is another key point needs to be paid attention to their applications. It is known that the delaminated MXenes flakes are normally uniformly dispersed in water forming colloidal solution. However, single MXene sheets are not indefinitely stable in environment with oxygen. Zhang et al. found that the degradation starts at the edges of Ti3C2Tx flakes and the colloidal solution gradually oxidized to TiO2 in open containers. On the other hand, the solution could be well
preserved when they were stored in hermetic Ar-filled bottle at 5 °C, because dissolved oxygen was eliminated.[40] Moreover, exposure to radiations can also cause the oxidation of MXene materials. Thus, it is recommended to refrigerate MXene solutions in an inert dark environment for storage and bubble with inert atmosphere during the material processing.
Besides the intrinsic compositions that predominantly determine the properties of different MXenes, it is noteworthy that the synthetic conditions significantly influence the properties of as-prepared MXenes, including the surface terminations.[41] Sang et al. reported that the defects concentration in the produced single-layer MXene Ti3C2Tx can be adjusted by the HF concentration.[42a] The lower HF concentration, shorter etching time, and sonication-free delamination would make MXenes with less defects and larger lateral size, and hence get higher electronic conductivity. It is reported that the defects of MXenes usually would react with active cations so that the initial coulombic efficiency will be decreased.[42b] Therefore, a mild etching condition is preferred to produce MXenes for batteries. However, the synthesis conditions such as low HF concentration and short etching period might reduce the yield of the products, developing an optimized condition is required to balance these counterparts
The versatile properties of MXenes allow the tuning for many applications including energy storage, reinforcements for composites, gas- and bio-sensors, water purification, lubrication, photo- and electro-catalysis, and electromagnetic interference shielding. MXenes also demonstrated unique electronic, plasmonic, optical, and thermoelectric properties, and hence can be utilized in many applications.[43] Overall, most of the reported MXenes possess combined features of good electronic conductivity, mechanic property, and hydrophilicity, which are appealing to the electrochemical energy storage application.[44]

sections.heading: 3. MXene-Based 2D Materials for Energy Storage
sections.text:
During the past decades, the consumption of fossil fuels has caused greenhouse gas emissions and worldwide climate change.[45] Thus, many countries have dedicated efforts to develop sustainable clean energy to relieve their dependence on fossil fuels. However, most renewable energy sources such as solar, wind and tidal energies are intermittent, depending on natural conditions to generate power.[46] Therefore, energy storage systems are needed to store the energy harvested from nature and convert to electricity for consumers on demand. Currently, energy storage systems such as rechargeable lithium batteries and supercapacitors have been preliminarily applied to electric vehicles to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Furthermore, next-generation smart electricity grids demand high energy, high power, and outstanding long-term properties to ensure consistent energy supply. MXene-based materials with high performance for energy storage systems are critical to integrate renewable energy resources into practical applications. In following content, we outline recent research progresses on nanoengineering of 2D MXenes and their derivatives with enhanced performance for energy storage, including lithiumion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, lithium–sulfur batteries, and supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 3.1. 2D MXene and Its Derivatives for Lithium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries have occupied the power source for laptop computers, mobile phones, digital cameras and videos, because of their enhanced energy densities, which are 2–3 times the energy per unit weight and volume compared to conventional rechargeable batteries. Since the first commercialized of the rechargeable lithium batteries in the 1990s, their research and development (R&D) has progressed rapidly.[12] Development of electric vehicles (EV) requests high power systems which can operate under high current conditions. In rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, the high rate charge/discharge process can degrade the electrochemical properties of lithium-ion batteries. It is crucial, therefore, to develop novel materials or technologies to enhance the electrochemical performance of rechargeable lithium batteries. MXenes are competitive with other 2D materials for high power lithium-ion battery applications owing to their wide chemical and structural varieties.[47] Theoretical calculations can predict MXenes as the most promising candidates for many energy storage applications.[48] Figure 2a,b shows structure of M2C, which makes up of a hexagonal graphene layer capped on both sides by a transition metal layer. The selective removal of the A atoms from MAX material (e.g., Ti2AlC) leads to the formation of 2D carbides such as Ti2C. The charge density difference Li intercalation in MXenes terminated with hydrogen or oxygen is shown in Figure 2c,d. This example clearly demonstrates that different functional groups cause significant changes in intercalation behavior of MXenes. It was found that MXenes with low formula weights, such as V2C, Ti2C, Sc2C, and Nb2C, are the most promising candidates due to their high theoretical gravimetric capacities.[49] Due to the strong bonds between M and X, it is assumed that metal ions only diffuse between the MXene sheets. Because Ti3C2 has one inactive TiC layer, Ti2C has higher gravimetric capacitance than that of Ti3C2. This was
also experimentally confirmed and provided evidence that the specific capacity of Ti2CTx for Li+ uptake is much higher than that of Ti3C2Tx obtained in the same method.[50]
It is reported that the capacity of MXenes is not completely determined by its formula weight.[51] Furthermore, although Nb atoms are heavier than Ti atoms, the specific capacity of Nb2CTx is higher than that for Ti2CTx. This result can be partially explained by the complicated feature of ion storage. The property of functional groups on surface is one special factor that can affect the performance of MXene materials.[52] After HF etching, the surface of MXenes is mostly covered by OH functional groups. Calculations of the Li-ion storage in such OH terminated MXenes show that insufficient capacity is observed. The Li-ion storage capacity with O terminated MXenes possessing the highest capacities after high-temperature treatment to minimize OH terminations, strongly suggesting the dependence of capacity to surface functional groups. Calculated Li diffusion barriers also suggest high lithium ion mobilities in oxygen terminated MXenes owing to their favor to lithium ion transport.[53] It is also reported that amine-assisted delamination of Nb2AlC can produce predominantly oxygen-terminated Nb2C MXenes. Notably, this delamination process only leads to highly separated Nb2CTx flakes from multilayer stacks without introducing any additional oxidation.[54] Besides functional groups on the surface, cations (e.g., Sn4+) on MXene also greatly affect the electrochemical performance. With inspiration of the unique uptake behavior of highly conductive Ti3C2 MXene, Sn4+ ion decorated Ti3C2 nanocomposites can be obtained via a facile polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-assisted liquid-phase immersion process.[55]
The key features of intercalation behavior of ions have been theoretically reported and experimentally confirmed. In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) can be used to investigate the mechanism of lithium ion storage in Ti3C2Tx. It was found that there is a continuous change in the oxidation state of the transition metal (e.g., titanium) during charge and discharge up

MXene-based composites nanosheets also exhibit fast and stable lithium storage. The MXene nanosheets not only enable reversible ion and electron transport at the interface due to its high conductivity but also prevent the active nanostructures from aggregation during intercalation/deintercalation perform as an underlying substrate. Liu et al. presented a general route to simply self-assemble transition metal oxide (TMO) nanostructures (SnO2 nanowires and TiO2 nanorods) on the surface of MXene (Ti3C2) (Figure 3).[57a] By minimizing the surface energy, the TMOs can be automatically self-assembled on the surface of the MXene flakes via a van der Waals interactions while the nanostructured TMO and MXene flakes are mixed together in tetrahydrofuran (THF). Thus, micelle-like heterostructures can be obtained. The resulting TMO/MXene composites exhibit excellent electrochemical properties for lithium-ion batteries, attributing to the excellent synergistic effect between the two building blocks. Many other reports have demonstrated that TMO/MXene materials can be design for high power/ energy electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries.[57] Besides,

By combining MXenes with active materials with high capacity (e.g., metal oxides, silicon), the synergistic improvement can be achieved. Optimizing above mentioned parameters is the key to achieve the maximum performance of MXenes for lithium-ion batteries.

sections.heading: 3.2. MXenes and Their Composites for Sodium-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
During the past decades, tremendous efforts have been made to develop attractive rechargeable battery systems for portable electronic devices and electric vehicles because of growing cost and limited lithium sources in nature.[61a] Nowadays,
sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) represent the promising systems for large-scale energy storage owing to the abundance and low cost of sodium.[61] However, due to the larger size of sodiumions, the dynamics of sodium ion diffusion in solid state materials needs to be improved. An effective solution is to develop nanosized electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries with high rate performance.[62] The diffusion time will be dramatically decreased by reducing the pathways for sodium ion insertion/extraction. On the other hand, the ionic conductivity can be also relatively affected by increasing the electronic conductivity, according to the neutralization of charge in solid state electrode materials. Therefore, MXenes and their nanocomposites have been reported as excellent electrode materials for high performance sodium-ion batteries.[63]
Ions with various sizes can be accommodated between the 2D layers of Mn+1XnTx. making MXene applicable for sodiumion batteries. It is predicted that the formation of an additional metal layer Na or other ions would lead to double the capacity. Furthermore, owing to surface chemistry tunability and chemical/structural variability, different MXenes can provide working potentials in a wide range, which makes them applicable as either cathodes or anodes.[64]
The intercalation mechanism of sodium ions towards Ti3C2X (X = F−, OH−, and O− groups) materials are disclosed at the atomic level. Theoretical studies show that there are low diffusion barriers in surface functionalized MXenes for Na and Al ions, as shown in Figure 4. Additionally, the Na ions can be electrochemically inserted/extracted to the Ti3C2X lattice reversibly via a two-phase transition and a subsequent solidsolution reaction. It shows that the Na ions can easily diffuse within Ti3C2X. Therefore, Ti3C2X exhibits outstanding high rate property and long-term stability as an anode material for the Na-ion batteries.[65] Experimental results remarkably agree with the theoretic calculation regarding high-rate performance for several MXenes.[66] MXene-based electrodes at rates up to 10 C decay in the vicinity of 50 mAh g−1.[67]
When the thickness of 2D titanium carbide down to atomic scale (monolayer TiC3), it will achieve the highest theoretic capacity up to 1278 mAh g−1. Meanwhile, first principles calculation demonstrates that open-circuit voltage and low barrier energy can be found in monolayer TiC3, as shown in Figure 5. It should be noted that TiC3 retains metallic state after alloying two-layer Na atoms, ensuring good electronic conductivity and leading to ultralong cycle life.[68] These intriguing features make the TiC3 monolayer, namely a metalrich MXene, a promising anode material for SIBs compared with other multilayered MXenes.[69]
Besides controlling thickness of MXenes, rational design of hierarchical porous structure can also introduce high sodium ion storage. Zhao et al. reported a self-assembly method, which cast 2D Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets onto the surface of spherical poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA). Then hollow spheres and 3D macroporous architectures can be obtained from a hard template approach.[70] Owing to the excellent contacts between spheres and metallic conductivity of Ti3C2Tx, the as-prepared 3D macroporous Ti3C2Tx films were flexible, free standing, and highly conductive. sections.heading: 3.3. MXene-Based Composites for Lithium–Sulfur Batteries

Recently, Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries (LSBs) have attracted extensive attention owing to their remarkably high theoretical specific capacity and energy density compared to those of lithium-ion batteries.[75] Although the average voltage plateaus of lithium–sulfur batteries lie at a lower value (2.2 V vs Li+/Li) compared with other cathode materials, the sulfur electrode can
deliver a high theoretical capacity of 1672 mAh g−1 and an excellent energy density of 2567 Wh kg−1 based on the formation of Li2S product, which are about 5–10 times higher than conventional cathodes for lithium-ion batteries.[76] Lithium–sulfur batteries also have many advantages, including low cost, abundance of sulfur, wide operating temperature range, and prolonged cycle life.

Thus, the conductivity of sulfur/carbon cathodes can be effectively enhanced and the dissolution of polysulfides in organic electrolyte can be minimized. Computational calculations have been applied to investigated the anchoring effect of lithium polysulfides on various 2D materials.[77] The results demonstrate that MXene materials exhibit excellent adsorption features with Li2Sx species, whereas charge transfer number from clusters of S atoms determines the binding strength. The polysulfides (Li2S4, Li2S6, Li2S8) can be entrapped by both bare and hydroxyl terminated MXenes. In contrary, other sulfides (Li2S and Li2S2) can be confined by -O group and bare MXenes, resulting in the enhancement on utilization of active materials of sulfur. These outcomes of such investigations give inspiration for designing various S/MXene composites for lithium–sulfur batteries.
Ti2CTx and Ti3C2Tx have been widely used as conductive sulfur hosts for lithium–sulfur batteries, resulting in remarkably enhanced stability and cyclability due to the strong interaction between polysulfide species and functional groups on MXene.[78] Liang et al. synthesized 2D conductive MXene phases as excellent sulfur battery hosts due to their high underlying metallic conductivity and self-functionalized surfaces (Figure 8).[79] The S/Ti2C composites phenomenon containing 70 wt% S exhibited stable long-term cycling performance due to the strong interaction between polysulfide species and Ti atoms on the surface,
proved by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy investigations. The cathodes display excellent cycling performance with high specific capacity close to 1200 mAh g−1 at a C/5 current rate. A capacity retention of 80% can be achieved up to 400 cycles at a C/2 current rate. MXenes not only provide a conductive matrix that accommodates volume change but also adsorb polysulfide molecules so that the dissolution of polysulfides in organic electrolyte can be minimized. By using this principle, Liang et al. developed interweaving carbon nanotubes between the MXene layers which create a porous, conductive network with high polysulfide absorptivity. This hierarchical MXene/CNT structure enables high loading (5.5 mg cm−2) as a sulfur host with excellent performance for lithium–sulfur batteries.[80] MXenes can be also utilized as additives[81] in cathodes and membranes[82] to extend the cyclability of lithium–sulfur batteries.
Many attempts have been dedicated to improving the adsorption of MXene materials to polysulfides for Li–S batteries. Bao et al. reported a rational synthesis of crumpled N-Ti3C2Tx nanosheets via thermal annealing of negatively charged metallic Ti3C2Tx flakes and positively charged melamine (Figure 9).[83] Crumpled N-doped MXene nanosheets with strong chemical and physical entrapping of polysulfides can be utilized as a novel sulfur host for lithium–sulfur batteries. This nitrogen doping strategy enables a desirable porous structure with high pore volume so that high sulfur loading rate up to 5.1 mg cm−2 can be achieved. To load high content of sulfur, MXene can be combined with CNT or graphene to form hierarchical structure with large pore volume for sulfur loading.[85] Particularly, Dong et al. reported an all-MXene-based flexible and integrated cathode. As shown in Figure 10, flexible lithium–sulfur batteries with integrated configuration can be assembled by using 3D alkalized Ti3C2 MXene/S host (a-Ti3C2-S) and Ti3C2 MXene/polypropylene (PP) separator.[85b] As a result, the as-prepared integrated electrode exhibits a high reversible capacity, low overpotential and outstanding rate capacity. More importantly, this free-standing all-MXene-based cathode excludes the use of an Al foil current collector, which is promising for next-generation flexible energy storage devices. This configuration of all-MXene-based cathode and separator is highly applicable to manufacture many all-nanosheet-like cathodes owing to many options of MXenes for high energy/ power lithium–sulfur batteries.
Compared with conventional conductive hosts (e.g., carbon) for sulfur cathodes, MXenes are more instinct in polarization so that the MXene matrix can effectively entrap polysulfides during the cycling for lithium–sulfur batteries. Functionalization of MXenes can further improve the adsorption capability to lithium polysulfides, thereby dissolving the shuttle-effect in lithium–sulfur batteries. Moreover, designing of hierarchical MXenes with 3D porous structure will enhance the mass loading of sulfur in cathode so that the integrated capacity can be greatly promoted. Besides cathodes and separators, MXenes can also suppress growth of lithium dendrites, improving the properties of lithium metal anodes for lithium–sulfur batteries.[86]

sections.heading: 3.4. MXene-Based Materials for High Performance Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Supercapacitors have attracted great attention due to their high-power density than conventional batteries.[87] Thus, supercapacitors are considered as the best candidates for next generation high power systems. There are two typical categories of storage mechanisms for supercapacitors. The first one

is electrical double layer capacitor (EDLC), where the charges are stored in Helmholtz double layer near the surfaces of the electrode materials. In an ideal EDLC, the supercapacitor presents a classic rectangular cyclic voltammograms without any redox reaction, resulting in outstanding power performance.[88,89] Since the charges are reserved on the surface of electrode materials, the specific energy density of supercapacitors is limited.[90] The capacity of an EDLC model is proportional to the surface area of the electrode. Therefore, adjusting the SA of the electrode material is the key solution to enhance capacitance.[91–94] The other category is pseudocapacitor, exhibiting faradaic redox reactions during charge/discharge. In the pseudocapacitor systems, the redox reactions occur on or near the electrode surface, thereby storing relatively more capacitance than EDLC.[95] The current pseudocapacitance electrode materials are mainly of metal oxide and conductive polymer.[96,97] The size of electrode materials affects the performance of pseudocapacitance. The faradaic redox reaction in nanoscale

MXene-based materials have great potential to be applied to the high-performance supercapacitors. First, MXenes can be intercalated by both polar organic molecules and metal ions. A wide a various of mono-/multi-valent cations (e.g., Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, and NH4+) can chemically or electrochemically intercalate into MXenes, thereby exhibiting high volume capacity.[98,99] Second, high conductive MXene provides fast electronic transfer in to other active materials and promotes the electrochemical performance of composites. In situ XAS results reveal that the MXene (Ti3C2Tx) shows the pseudocapacitive behavior while coupling with oxides.[100] The surface functional groups (-OH,-F, -O) also affect the adsorption of ions and contribute to the volume capacity.[101]
Rational design of MXene materials is critical to achieve high-performance electrode materials for supercapacitors. Particularly, porosity, distance of interlayers and the functional groups on surface greatly affect the properties of MXene-based materials. For instance, the fleet dispersal property of ions can be observed and the cation dipoles direction can be well organized in nanopores.[102] The large interlayer distance of MXene facilitates the insertion of organic molecules or metal ions in supercapacitors.[103] Mashtalir et al. reported that the hydrazine intercalation causes the reducing of superficial groups (e.g., -F, -OH) of the MXene, forming a pillaring effect between MXene layers, thereby enlarging the interlayer distance and enhancing the accessibility of ions/molecules. Ti3C2Tx has been extensively studied for supercapacitors. The Ti3C2Tx paper electrodes exhibit outstanding volumetric capacitance in neutral and basic electrolytes which exceed the best all-carbon EDLCs and are comparable to recently reported activated graphene–based electrodes.[104] A volumetric capacitance over 900 F cm−3 can be obtained for a rolled pure Ti3C2Tx clay electrode in electrolyte of 1 m H2SO4. Because protons are the smallest cations so that they can access the largest amount of the electrochemically active sites. Additionally, ideal capacitive behavior of Ti3C2Tx can be observed even at high charge/discharge rates.[20] MXenes also display outstanding cyclability, without capacitance fading even after 10 000 cycles. Furthermore, thin MXene electrodes on flexible substrates illustrate even better rate performance.[105]
In situ XRD results reveal that the distance of the interlamination is enlarged by the inserted ions and is shortened by the ions deintercalation. So the MXenes pole will reveal the volumetric shrinkage and swelling in the cycle charge/discharge process. Therefore, the stable interlayer is helpful to maintain the stratified structure.[106] The conjugated polymer interlamination is a useful approach to improve capacitance. For example, Ti3C2Tx layers with insertion of polyfluorene derivatives can achieve high volumetric capacitance and outstanding retention.[107] Strategies for facilitating ion transport by designing nanoarchitectures with large porosity results in low volumetric energy storage and long ion transport paths for high charge/ discharge rates. Xia et al. reported that vertical alignment of 2D MXene nanosheets enables directional ion transport, leading to thickness-independent electrochemical performances in
thick MXene films, as shown in Figure 11.[108] By using this technique, the resulting electrode films demonstrate excellent performance that is mostly independent of film thickness up to 200 µm. This result makes 2D MXene materials highly attractive for supercapacitor applications.
Besides, the surface modification of MXene also enhances the electrochemical performance of the MXene-based electrodes.[109] The functional groups on the MXene surface can be eliminated by methods such as alkalization and calcination, decreasing the electron diffusion path and expands the interlayer spacing of MXenes. Therefore, improved electronic conductivity can be obtained, and hence achieve excellent electrochemical performance for supercapacitors.[110] Lukatskaya et al. demonstrated that 2D transition metal carbides (MXenes) can operate at higher rates than those of conventional EDLCs (Figure 12). Moreover, they also provide higher areal and volumetric capacitance than carbon, transition metal oxides electrically and conducting polymers.[111] Two rational designs were applied for MXene electrode architectures with improved ion accessibility. As a result, a macroporous Ti3C2Tx MXene film delivered outstanding capacitance at high scan rates, overtaking the best carbon-based supercapacitors. MXene hydrogels can deliver excellent volumetric capacitance which reaches the volumetric performance of RuO2.
DFT calculations reveal that doping technique can modify the MXene by reducing its band gap. Both cation and anion can be applied to the doping technology to improve the electrochemical performance. For example, the band gap of Sc2CF2 can be decreased from 0.96 to 0.24 eV by introducing the dopant of Sn atom.[112] On the other hand, Wen et al. synthesized the nitrogen atom doped Ti3C2Tx, and achieved enhanced electrochemical performance. In the N doping process, the nitrogen atom replaces the C atom so that the c lattice parameter of Ti3C2Tx film enlarges from 1.92 to 2.46 nm. This treatment enables to higher surface area and electrochemical activity sites, thereby improving the electrochemical capacitance.[113,114]
In addition to the liquid electrolyte supercapacitors, MXenes can be used in solid electrolyte supercapacitors with high volumetric capacitance.[115] The MXenes show high elastic moduli when are pulled by a certain direction, which is helpful for the applications of the all solid-state supercapacitors.[116,117] Zhang et al. prepared highly transparent and conductive Ti3C2Tx films via a spin-casting method for solid-state supercapacitors.[117] Transparent films with high transmittance (93%) demonstrate excellent DC conductivities. These highly transparent, conductive Ti3C2Tx films display outstanding volumetric capacitance for supercapacitors. Asymmetric solid-state supercapacitor films can be prepared by mixing Ti3C2Tx and single-walled carbon nanotube, exhibiting high capacitance, energy density, and long lifetime (up to 20 000 cycles without capacitance decay). Therefore, Ti3C2Tx films are promising for future transparent, conductive, capacitive electrodes, which can be applied to many high-performance wearable and portable devices.
For supercapacitor application, many approaches such as interlayer adjustment, doped modifying, surface modification, and combining with other special materials can increase electrochemical performances of the MXene-based materials. These methods have remarkably improved the properties of the MXene

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
This review highlights the latest research progress on 2D MXene materials for energy storage applications, including lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, lithium–sulfur batteries and supercapacitors. Although extensive investigations have been explored on these 2D materials in the past decades, there are still many challenges hindering their practical applications.
From the aspect of material synthesis, the main challenge is how to make 2D materials as thin as possible, by using effective exfoliation techniques. It is obvious that the specific surface area and reactivity of 2D MXene materials will be boosted by reducing the thickness dimension. It has been proven that the functional groups on surface greatly affect the electrochemical performance of MXenes. On the other hand, the morphological modification is also important for increasing active sites. The control of porosity and curvature of 2D MXene nanomaterials can generate high surface area and pore volume, which
will enhance the performances for energy storage applications such as supercapacitors and rechargeable batteries. Therefore, each application has special constraints on the structure or composition of 2D MXene materials. For lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries, the electrode materials are preferred to be defect-free or functional group-free because this usually leads to high initial Coulombic efficiency. The shuttle effect of polysulfides should be suppressed so that good cycle life can be achieved for lithium–sulfur batteries. This requires the MXene materials to have excellent capability to trap polysulfide molecules when used as cathode hosts in lithium–sulfur batteries. Supercapacitors request high specific surface area, which can be realized by introducing high porosity. According to these special requirements, nanofabrication and nanoengineering provide possibilities for achieving all these demands, as interpreted in main text of this review.
There are still many other challenges to develop of MXenebased materials. The family of MXene needs to be extended to develop more Mn+1XnTx with different metals (M) and functions of T and x. Controlling and modifying MXenes’ surfaces will benefit to obtain MXenes with desirable properties. For example, MXenes with functional groups on surface may lead to low conductivity. Synthesizing MXenes without functional groups will result in achieving excellent electrochemical performance. Furthermore, it is still difficult to prepare large-scale single layered

MXenes. Success in addressing above-mentioned issues will extend a wide range of applications for MXene-based materials.
The 2D MXene materials reviewed in this manuscript can be also applied for some other special energy storage devices, which are not presented in detail. These possible applications include:
Flexible Electrodes: Generally, MXene (or their hybrid composite) can be directly used as flexible electrodes via filtration assembly methods. MXenes may also be applied to free-standing electrodes if combined with 1D or 2D substrates (CNTs, carbon fibers, graphene etc.). Those current collectorfree electrodes will deliver higher energy and power, which is suitable for advanced flexible electronics (e.g., wearable devices).
All-Solid-State Batteries: It is well recognized that the allsolid-state batteries are the ultimate batteries owing to their high energy density and safe feature. Due to the unique physical properties of MXenes, they can be applied to the components of all-solid-state batteries: cathode, lithium metal anode, and solid electrolyte. For instance, the development of lithium metal anodes is the key factor to industrialize high power energy storage systems. Preliminary results have proved that 2D hosts (e.g., graphene) can effectively accommodate lithium (or sodium) metal and prevent the anode from forming metal dendrites. It is also believed that by using appropriate coating technology with MXene materials, the plating of lithium-ion on lithium metal anode can be eventually solved and lithium metal–based composites can be commercialized as anode materials for energy storage.
Hybrid Capacitors: Supercapacitors have long term stability due to their highly reversible charge storage process, and can be both rapidly charged and discharged with high power. The main disadvantage of the supercapacitors is their low energy density (compared to batteries). This means that the amount of energy stored in a supercapacitor is lower than the energy of a battery of equal size or mass. Combination of the electrodes for lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors will compensate the drawbacks from each part. Anchoring nanoparticles on 2D sheet-like substrates is a feasible method to achieve excellent electrochemical performances. By designing the structure and composition of hybrid capacitors, a hybrid system can obtain reasonable high energy density and power density.
When dealing with the design of 2D MXene materials for energy storage, it is crucial to find solutions that combine reasonable costs with outstanding performance. In other words, specific capacity, energy density, power density, lifetime, cost, and safety, should be well balanced. Challenges must be addressed to satisfy the realization of above-mentioned energy storage devices. To overcome these challenges, novel methods and techniques should be developed for preparing 2D MXene materials with excellent chemical stability and durability to enhance the performance of the resulting devices. Therefore, resolving the above-mentioned challenges will benefit the adventure of 2D MXene nanomaterials in energy storage applications.
